moves.1. e4 e6: recognize this? this is a opening for black in a game i also annotated
moves.2. f3 c5: can someone please tell me what white's doing?
moves.3. c3 Nc6: for black, moving to d5 is forfeiting the opening, entering middle game. note that I do see the impending trouble of e5, thus Nc6
moves.5. c4 d5: I'm ready to start the offensive.
moves.6. cxd5 exd5 7. exd5 Nxd5 8. d3 Qe7+: why white responds like white does is a mystery, does anyone know or is it an error?
moves.9. Kd2:
should i have done Qe3+! ? I could have mate in two after 9...Qe3+10Kc2Nb4/e4#.
this opening works pretty well against e4 with a pawn push.
moves.9... Nxf4: however, i did not notice the mate in two, so....
moves.10. b3: fiancetto? its a little late for that
moves.10... Bf5: coordinated attack on d3 seemed appealing at the moment.
moves.11. Qf3 Qe5 12. Qh3: this was a tactical blunder. technically I could have won with a good game if i had seen the mate in two. I wish I saw that. stupid 2 min 5 second delay
moves.12... Bxh3 13. gxh3 Qxa1: that was not an error on his part, that was tactics on mine. I want to take credit for something.
moves.14. Ba3 Qxa2+ 15. Kc3 Nd5+ 16. Kc4 Ne3+: mate in two, white resigns. here's what would've happened.
moves.18. Bb4 Qxb4#: so, did this work? i know there are some problems with it. such as the fact that i never castled, and my queen was in danger a lot of the time. but you have to admit that mate around move 9.
